notes: Comments can be written either: // or multiline: /*    */
Primitive data types include string, symbol, number, boolean, undefined, and null
As of ES6 variable assignment is done with 'let' and 'const'.
JavaScript is 'loosely typed meaning that you don't have to declare the types of variables.
An array is an ordered list of values
Common method arrays include: pop (remove last), push (add to the end), shift (remove from beginning), unshift (add to the beginning)
Sets are an array-like data structure that doesn't allow for duplicate values.
Maps are similar to hashes, or hash tables, or dictionaries.
Maps can use any data type as a key; they have a size property; solely used for storage and retrieval; values can't be accessed directly
Functions can be declared using function declarations, expressions, arrow notation, or with the function constructor.

links.description: What is the difference between null and undefined in JavaScript?, Stack Overflow
Basics of Hash Tables, Hacker Earth

notes: Strings are compared character by character using 'lexographical' order. If all the charaters are the same and they are the same length then they are equal. Otherwise the longer string is greater.
Everything in javascript is a primitive value or an object.
The value of 'this' is the object the method is being called upon, unless it.
Unlike many other programming languages, Javascript uses an 'unbound' this (it's value is defined at run-time)
